In this case, we have 2 trials so far, and both have resulted in low-quality products. The probability of 2 low-quality products in a row is (1/2) x (1/2) = 1/4. Since the probability of a product being high-quality is 50%, the probability of the current product being high-quality, given that no high-quality products have been sold so far, is 1 - 1/4 = 3/4.
